evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident during the early phase of the hist_pair_engine_t1 event on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown is resistant to defeaters as alternative explanations such as equipment failure or external interference do not account for the observed coordination issues among the crew.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features observed in the hist_pair_engine_t1_early event, including misaligned crew actions and failure to share critical information timely.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS aircraft, registration 9H-QAA, specifically during the historical pair engine T1 early phase on December 25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution demonstrates resistance to common defeaters such as pilot error misclassification, sensor inaccuracies, and procedural ambiguities within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t1_early scenario.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in pushback operations, including timing, crew actions, and environmental conditions relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident during the early phase of the hist_pair_engine_t1 event on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25.

assumptions: Communication via interphone and interaction between tug instructor and trainee driver reflect crew coordination
The event phase corresponds to the early phase of hist_pair_engine_t1
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If the event was caused solely by procedural deviation without coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 shows active communication and coordination attempts but also procedural deviations leading to the aircraft overrunning the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, supporting a communication/coordination breakdown during the early phase.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from communication breakdown

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features observed in the hist_pair_engine_t1_early event, including misaligned crew actions and failure to share critical information timely.

assumptions: Assuming that the trainee's decision to stop and instructor's takeover indicates coordination issues
Assuming that the described interactions reflect misaligned crew actions and communication timing
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely sharing of critical information without misaligned actions
If procedural deviations better explained the event per discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows communication and coordination among crew with role changes and advising, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown aligning with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication was fully effective or partially failed
